bibl.title: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to L.M. Fisher, November 1, 1922

div1.p: [Carter] sends Fisher information on impounded waters. He comments on the malaria and mosquito situation in North and South Carolina.

div1.head: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to L.M. Fisher, November 1, 1922
div1.opener:
N. M. C.
Im'd Water
Fisher
/LC
2121 California St., N. W.
, D. C.,
November 1, 1922.
Mr. L. M. Fisher,
Sanitary Engineer, U. S. P. H. S.
Care State Board of Health,
Columbia, S. C.
dear Mr. Fisher:
div1.p:
I am sending you a lot of MSS in re Impounded Waters. I doubt
if you will thank me for them in addition to the special letters I
have written on the same subject. Still, the more general informa-
tion you have on the subject the better you can envisage any spe-
cial problem and--if you have not completed your Report to Dr. Ran-
kin--that too will be better and redound both to yourself and to
the Service. I rather hope for yourself, however, that it is off
your hands.

I will ask you to return these papers to me when you have read
them as I may want them when I get to Chatanooga. I have offered to
go there three days before the meeting so that if Dr. Welsh wants a
consultation on the Alabama Regulations I would be available. I am
rather hoping that my letter of October 3rd. to Hazlehurst will ren-
der a personal meeting unnecessary, as all travelling and hotel ex-
penses now are borne by myself and while I am willing to spend some
of my money--as I have spent much of my life--in helping the control of
malaria, I do not wish to do so unnecessarily.

I wish much you could have gone to Marion before the rains and
judged of the ponds prior to the washing out of the creeks. I am in -
in-
2.
clined to think that the larvae you found in the pond itself were wash-
ed in. I don't think their being small--provided you made the exami-
nation soon after a rain--would be any criterion of their origen one
way or the other. I don't know that small larvae drown more easily
than large ones. They usually come down stream clinging to leaves: bits
of floatage etc.

At Blewetts Falls we dipped a bight at the mouth of the stream one
afternoon. It was negative, while the stream itself was breeding in
eddies and side pools. There came a rain that night and many larvae--
all sizes--were taken in the bight next morning and in the bucket in
which we carried them--we were developing larvae then on a large scale
and used buckets, not bottles emptying in the water from our dippers--
we found babies, showing that we had poured in some eggs, which quite
certainly washed down stream.

I hope that you examined the South side of the Catawba Pond, in
which few streams flow, as here the element of washing down would have
been to a great extent eliminated. The reason I don't think the Pond
has been breeding mosquitoes--except those washed in from streams--is
because the August examination of 1921--careful and painstaking--was
negative, and to me unexpectedly negative.

If the temperature around Marion was like that at Winnsboro when
I was there, production of Anopheles after October 9th. would have been
of little sanitary importance, as it was too cold while I was there for
the developement of the plasmodia in the mosquito, which requires, as
you know, a somewhat higher temperature than the mosquito itself does.

At Badin there has always been breeding in the Pond and in not a
few places. In one place--just in front of Mr. Elliott's--is the only
place in which I ever saw breeding--possibly made, certainly increased
by clearing.

A large amount of malaria about Palmerville and Badin itself has
been destroyed by the Pond. In the Beaver Dam Creek section, however, including Glady Fork, it has been increased. As Palmersville and Badin
are thickly settled--and the other section rather sparsely--the good
overbalanced the evil, yet it was the factor of amount of population
that did this, as I heard that practically every house in the Beaver
Dam Creek section claimed to have malaria. I don't think any measures
that are practicable can give much control at Badin. LePrince and my-
self advised Mr. Martin before the Pond was made to purchase all the
land at a reasonable distance from the Pond: that we saw no means of
reasonable control of malaria in this section. I, of course, could
live there in a screened house with safety, but those who did live there
couldn't. Oiling log-jams would help, of course. In ordinary summer
weather, 14 days is the Maximum interval for good work. I doubt if the
introduction of Gambusia now could give anything but a temporary bene-
fit. The Pond is six years old. If they were introduced early and in
a number of places they should then have reached their normal limit in
the Pond long before this and while the introduction of large numbers
would temporarily raise this limit in the places where introduced, yet
the number would soon fall to the normal and no permanent good be done.

I don't want to criticise Dr. Moore, but while intravenous in-
jection is the quickest way to cure an attack of malaria, it is quite
troublesome and is certainly no more efficacious than quinine by the
mouth. Of course, if one could get the people to take quinine one could
control malaria--possibly eliminate it--but they won't, and there's an
end to it.
div1.closer: Very truly yours, Assistant Surgeon General. Enclosures.
